1 Introdution

Thus far, we have computed the electric field without using Gauss‚Äôs law, but the geometry and symmetry of the systems considered are such that Gauss‚Äôs law applies.

1.1 Definition of D \mathbf{D} D and Derivation of Gauss‚Äô Law for Dielectrics

We have shown that induced dipoles will form when an electric field exists in a dielectric. The electric field at a given location in the dielectric depends on the electric field due to all of the other dipoles and the external electric field. So, as it stands, to compute the electric field in a dielectric ‚Ä¶ you need to know the electric field in the dielectric.

One way of resolving this is to assume that the electric field in a dielectric is reduced by a factor of what it would have been if the dielectric was not there. This is only sometimes correct and is thus about as useful as the grammar rule ‚Äúi before e except after c‚Äù.

Gauss‚Äô Law can be used to find the correct answer for certain problems (the same types of problems where it is useful for calculating the electric field - problems with symmetry that allows simplification of the integral). More generally, special techniques are needed (Boundary Value Method and the Method of Images), both of which rely of Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics.

We being by first defining a new quantity related to E \mathbf{E} E, the oddly named electric displacement or electric flux density*, D \mathbf{D} D, which is also called the electric flux density,

D ‚â° œµ 0 E + P \mathbf{D}\equiv\epsilon_0\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P} D‚â°œµ0‚ÄãE+P

E \mathbf{E} E is the electric field, which is due to external electric fields and the electric field of the induced dipoles. P \mathbf{P} P is the polarization, which depends on E \mathbf{E} E. We are combining two things that are difficult to calculate to define D \mathbf{D} D, which perhaps unexpectedly, will be easier to calculate.

We also distinguish charges among those that are due to polarization, Q b o u n d Q_{bound} Qbound‚Äã, and the rest, Q f r e e Q_{free} Qfree‚Äã (again, naming choice could be clearer, but is standard):

Q = Q f r e e + Q b o u n d Q = Q_{free} + Q_{bound} Q=Qfree‚Äã+Qbound‚Äã

Next, write Gauss‚Äô Law in terms of D \mathbf{D} D, P \mathbf{P} P, Q f r e e Q_{free} Qfree‚Äã, and Q b o u n d Q_{bound} Qbound‚Äã:

Gauss‚Äô Law is

Œ¶ E ‚â° ‚àÆ S E ‚ãÖ d a = Q I n s i d e , S / œµ 0 \Phi_E\equiv\oint_{S} \mathbf{E}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S}/\epsilon_0 Œ¶E‚Äã‚â°‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖda=QInside,S‚Äã/œµ0‚Äã

substitution gives

‚àÆ S ( D / œµ 0 ‚àí P / œµ 0 ) ‚ãÖ d a = Q F r e e , i n s i d e , S / œµ 0 + Q B o u n d , i n s i d e , S / œµ 0 \oint_{S} (\mathbf{D}/\epsilon_0 - \mathbf{P}/\epsilon_0) \cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Free,inside,S}/\epsilon_0 + Q_{Bound,inside,S}/\epsilon_0 ‚àÆS‚Äã(D/œµ0‚Äã‚àíP/œµ0‚Äã)‚ãÖda=QFree,inside,S‚Äã/œµ0‚Äã+QBound,inside,S‚Äã/œµ0‚Äã

simplifying

‚àÆ S D ‚ãÖ d a ‚àí ‚àÆ S P ‚ãÖ d a = Q F r e e , i n s i d e , S + Q B o u n d , i n s i d e , S \oint_{S} \mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} - \oint_{S}\mathbf{P}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Free,inside,S}+ Q_{Bound,inside,S} ‚àÆS‚ÄãD‚ãÖda‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãP‚ãÖda=QFree,inside,S‚Äã+QBound,inside,S‚Äã

The second term on both sides of the equation are equal*, leaving

‚àÆ S D ‚ãÖ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ‚àÆS‚ÄãD‚ãÖda=QInside,S,free‚Äã

This is another form of Gauss‚Äô Law and is referred to here as Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics in integral form. It is also valid for non-dielectrics. In older textbooks, one often finds a discussion of electric displacement flux, Œ¶ D \Phi_D Œ¶D‚Äã

Œ¶ D ‚â° ‚àÆ S D ‚ãÖ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \Phi_D\equiv\oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} Œ¶D‚Äã‚â°‚àÆS‚ÄãD‚ãÖda=QInside,S,free‚Äã

before the electric flux

Œ¶ E ‚â° ‚àÆ S D ‚ãÖ d a = Q I n s i d e , S \Phi_E\equiv\oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S} Œ¶E‚Äã‚â°‚àÆS‚ÄãD‚ãÖda=QInside,S‚Äã

The equation for Œ¶ D \Phi_D Œ¶D‚Äã looks similar to that for Œ¶ E \Phi_E Œ¶E‚Äã, except that its right-hand side only refers to non-bound charges (‚Äúfree charges‚Äù) inside a surface and the factor of œµ 0 \epsilon_0 œµ0‚Äã is missing. The equations for Œ¶ E \Phi_E Œ¶E‚Äã and Œ¶ D \Phi_D Œ¶D‚Äã are equally valid, but Œ¶ D \Phi_D Œ¶D‚Äã should be used for dielectrics as it simplifies the solution.

*Using œÉ b = P ‚ãÖ n ^ \sigma_b = \mathbf{P}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{n}} œÉb‚Äã=P‚ãÖn^ and d a ‚â° n ^ d a d\mathbf{a}\equiv \hat{\mathbf{n}}da da‚â°n^da gives

‚àí ‚àÆ S P ‚ãÖ d a = ‚àí ‚àÆ S P ‚ãÖ n ^ d a = ‚àí ‚àÆ S œÉ b d a -\oint_{S}\mathbf{P}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = -\oint_{S}\mathbf{P}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}da = -\oint_{S}\sigma_bda ‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãP‚ãÖda=‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãP‚ãÖn^da=‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãœÉb‚Äãda

œÉ b \sigma_b œÉb‚Äã refers to charges ‚Äò‚Äôon‚Äô‚Äô, but not inside of, a Gaussian surface. Because we are talking about dipoles, there must be an equal an opposite number of charges just below, and so inside, the Gaussian surface. So Q B o u n d , e n c l o s e d = ‚àí ‚àÆ S œÉ b d a Q_{Bound,enclosed} = -\oint_{S}\sigma_bda QBound,enclosed‚Äã=‚àí‚àÆS‚ÄãœÉb‚Äãda.

1.2 Historical Origin and Units on D \mathbf{D} D

The units on electric displacement are

[ D ] = Coulomb m 2 [\mathbf{D}]=\frac{\text{Coulomb}}{\text{m}^2} [D]=m2Coulomb‚Äã

whereas for electric field

[ E ] = Newtons Coulomb [\mathbf{E}]=\frac{\text{Newtons}}{\text{Coulomb}} [E]=CoulombNewtons‚Äã

In a sense, D \mathbf{D} D is more natural quantity with regard to its units - because the units in its denominator are m 2 m^2 m2, it ‚Äò‚Äôseems‚Äô‚Äô like a quantity that you would want to integrate over an area. But then this leads to the awkward question of ‚ÄúFlux is usually a quantity fo ‚Äòstuff‚Äô flowing through a surface‚Äù. According to Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics, the ‚Äòstuff‚Äô has units of coulombs. But no actual charge flows through the surface?!‚Äù When the laws of electricity were being formulated, Faraday, Maxwell and others were very much influenced by the physics of fluid flow. The word ‚Äúflux‚Äù means flow. In Faraday‚Äôs 1837 experiment, he noted that it was if charge was induced on the outer sphere and was displaced by lines of force originating on the inner sphere. [https://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/Rarebook_treasures/QC503F211839_PDF/QC503F211839v2.pdf] [https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page%3AA_Treatise_on_Electricity_and_Magnetism_-_Volume_1.djvu/100 First reference of Maxwell to ‚Äúdisplacement‚Äù]

See also http://www.jpier.org/PIER/pier149/17.14092503.pdf

This is one of the many reasons why E&M is conceptually difficult. Consider Lord Kelvin‚Äôs opinion: ‚ÄúThat is why I take plain dynamics. I can get a model in plain dynamics; I cannot in electromagnetics.‚Äù [http://zapatopi.net/kelvin/quotes/]. Also ‚ÄúI have not had a moment‚Äôs peace or happiness in respect to electromagnetic theory since Nov. 28 1846.‚Äù [https://books.google.com/books?id=mN0TDAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA229&ots=mlKk9PJkji&dq=Nov.%2028%201846%20Faraday%20publication&pg=PA229#v=onepage&q=Nov.%2028%201846%20Faraday%20publication&f=false]. See [https://books.google.com/books?id=kdm9nmAkKvIC&lpg=PA1015&dq=November%2028%201846%20kelvin&pg=PA1015#v=onepage&q=November%2028%201846%20kelvin&f=false] for the relevance of the date.‚Äù

2 Using Gauss‚Äô Law for Dielectrics

Here is how Gauss‚Äô Law has can be used to resolve the issue for certain types of problems. First, compute D \mathbf{D} D using Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics. The charges in this version of the law refer to charges that we usually know about - their location and magnitude (this is the motivation for calling them ‚Äúfree‚Äù - we can freely, or at least more easily, modify their location and magnitude). Then, use P = œá e œµ 0 E \mathbf{P}=\chi_e\epsilon_0\mathbf{E} P=œáe‚Äãœµ0‚ÄãE and the definition of D \mathbf{D} D

D ‚â° œµ 0 E + P = œµ 0 E + œá e œµ 0 E \mathbf{D}\equiv\epsilon_0\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P}=\epsilon_0\mathbf{E}+\chi_e\epsilon_0\mathbf{E} D‚â°œµ0‚ÄãE+P=œµ0‚ÄãE+œáe‚Äãœµ0‚ÄãE

and solve for E \mathbf{E} E

E = D œµ 0 ( 1 + œá e ) \mathbf{E}=\frac{\mathbf{D}}{\epsilon_0(1+\chi_e)} E=œµ0‚Äã(1+œáe‚Äã)D‚Äã

Another common way of writing this is

E = D / œµ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon E=D/œµ

using the definition

œµ = ‚â° œµ 0 ( 1 + œá e ) \epsilon=\equiv\epsilon_0(1+\chi_e) œµ=‚â°œµ0‚Äã(1+œáe‚Äã)

œµ œµ 0 = œµ r ‚â° ( 1 + œá e ) \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon_0}=\epsilon_r\equiv(1+\chi_e) œµ0‚Äãœµ‚Äã=œµr‚Äã‚â°(1+œáe‚Äã)

They are a measure of the magnitude of the dielectric permittivity relative to the permittivity of free space.

To complicate matters, some references use dielectric constant Œ∫ \kappa Œ∫ or relative permittivity Œ∫ r \kappa_r Œ∫r‚Äã instead of œµ \epsilon œµ and œµ r \epsilon_r œµr‚Äã.

2.1 Problems

2.1.1 Dielectric Between Sheets of Charge

An infinite non-conducting sheet in the x = d x=d x=d plane has a charge density of ‚àí œÉ 0 -\sigma_0 ‚àíœÉ0‚Äã; An infinite non-conducting sheet in the x = ‚àí d x=-d x=‚àíd plane has a charge density of + œÉ 0 +\sigma_0 +œÉ0‚Äã, where œÉ 0 > 0 \sigma_0>0 œÉ0‚Äã>0. (That is, the sheet in the x = d x=d x=d plane is negatively charged and the sheet in the x = ‚àí d x=-d x=‚àíd plane is positively charged.)

Label key points on your plots in terms of œÉ 0 , d \sigma_0, d œÉ0‚Äã,d, and œµ 0 \epsilon_0 œµ0‚Äã. A diagram is given on the board.

  1. Plot the electric field as a function of x x x from x = ‚àí 2 d x=-2d x=‚àí2d to x = + 2 d x=+2d x=+2d.

  2. Plot the electric potential as a function of x x x from x = ‚àí 2 d x=-2d x=‚àí2d to x = + 2 d x=+2d x=+2d. Set the electric potential to zero at x = 0 x=0 x=0.

{| class=‚Äùwikitable collapsible collapsed‚Äù ! align=‚Äùleft‚Äù | Answer |- | Each sheet produces an electric field with magnitude œÉ 0 / ( 2 œµ 0 ) \sigma_0/(2\epsilon_0) œÉ0‚Äã/(2œµ0‚Äã). Electric field lines point towards negative sheet and away from the positive sheet. Because we are treating sheets are infinite, the electric field does not depend on distance from the sheet and electric field is perpendicular to the sheet. Because the sheets have equal and opposite charge, the electric field sums to zero in the regions x < ‚àí d x<-d x<‚àíd and x > d x>d x>d. Between the sheets, the electric fields add and are both in the + x ^ +\hat{\mathbf{x}} +x^-direction.

  • x < ‚àí d x < -d x<‚àíd, E = 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=0x^

  • ‚àí d < x < ‚àí d -d < x < -d ‚àíd<x<‚àíd, E = + œÉ 0 / œµ 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=+\sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=+œÉ0‚Äã/œµ0‚Äãx^

  • x > d x > d x>d, E = 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=0x^

We expect the electric potential to be the highest near the positive sheet as this is the location where a positive test charge will have the highest potential energy. We are given the potential at x = 0 x=0 x=0 - a reference potential must always be given or specified because differences in potential are what determine physical quantities of interest. We can approach this problem in two ways:

  1. Ask what V V V would give the correct E \mathbf{E} E when we use E = ‚àí ‚àá V = ‚àí x ^ ‚àÇ V / ‚àÇ x \mathbf{E}=-\nabla V = -\hat{\mathbf{x}}\partial V/\partial x E=‚àí‚àáV=‚àíx^‚àÇV/‚àÇx

  2. Use Œî V = ‚àí ‚à´ a b E ‚ãÖ d l \Delta V=-\int_a^b \mathbf{E}\cdot d\mathbf{l} ŒîV=‚àí‚à´ab‚ÄãE‚ãÖdl

From 1., we conclude that V V V must be linear with a negative slope of œÉ 0 / œµ 0 \sigma_0/\epsilon_0 œÉ0‚Äã/œµ0‚Äã between the sheets and it must be constant (and not necessarily zero) outside of the sheets. The given V ( 0 ) = 0 V(0)=0 V(0)=0 give the intercept as 0 0 0. The electric potential must be continuous and it does not change for x < ‚àí d x<-d x<‚àíd and x > d x>d x>d because the electric field is zero. So for x < ‚àí d x<-d x<‚àíd, the potential must be the same as it is at x = ‚àí d x=-d x=‚àíd and similar for x > d x>d x>d. These considerations give

  • x < ‚àí d x < -d x<‚àíd, V = œÉ 0 d / œµ 0 V=\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V=œÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã

  • ‚àí d < x < ‚àí d -d < x < -d ‚àíd<x<‚àíd, V = ‚àí œÉ 0 x / œµ 0 V=-\sigma_0x/\epsilon_0 V=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãx/œµ0‚Äã

  • x > d x > d x>d, V = ‚àí œÉ 0 d / œµ 0 V=-\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã

The second approach is to use Œ¥ V = V ( b ) ‚àí V ( a ) = ‚àí ‚à´ a b E ‚ãÖ d l \delta V= V(b)-V(a) = -\int_a^b \mathbf{E}\cdot d\mathbf{l} Œ¥V=V(b)‚àíV(a)=‚àí‚à´ab‚ÄãE‚ãÖdl in the different regions. In all regions, d l = x ^ d x d\mathbf{l}=\hat{\mathbf{x}}dx dl=x^dx. Choosing a = 0 a=0 a=0 and b = x b=x b=x, we have

Œî V = V ( b ) ‚àí V ( a ) = V ( x ) ‚àí V ( 0 ) = ‚àí ‚à´ 0 x + œÉ 0 / œµ 0 x ^ ‚Ä≤ ‚ãÖ x ^ ‚Ä≤ d x ‚Ä≤ = ‚àí œÉ 0 x / œµ 0 \Delta V = V(b)-V(a) = V(x)-V(0)=-\int_0^x +\sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}}'\cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}'dx'=-\sigma_0x/\epsilon_0 ŒîV=V(b)‚àíV(a)=V(x)‚àíV(0)=‚àí‚à´0x‚Äã+œÉ0‚Äã/œµ0‚Äãx^‚Ä≤‚ãÖx^‚Ä≤dx‚Ä≤=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãx/œµ0‚Äã

where x ^ ‚ãÖ x ^ = 1 \hat{\mathbf{x}}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{x}}=1 x^‚ãÖx^=1 has been used and the dummy integration variable was set to x ‚Ä≤ x' x‚Ä≤. Since V ( 0 ) = 0 V(0)=0 V(0)=0, we have, V ( x ) = ‚àí œÉ 0 x / œµ 0 V(x)=-\sigma_0x/\epsilon_0 V(x)=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãx/œµ0‚Äã, which applies only to the region for which E = + œÉ 0 / œµ 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=+\sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=+œÉ0‚Äã/œµ0‚Äãx^. This equation can be used to find V ( d ) = ‚àí œÉ 0 d / œµ 0 V(d)=-\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V(d)=‚àíœÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã and V ( ‚àí d ) = œÉ 0 d / œµ 0 V(-d)=\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V(‚àíd)=œÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã. To find the potential for x > d x>d x>d, we can use

Œî V = V ( x ) ‚àí V ( d ) = ‚àí ‚à´ d x 0 x ^ ‚Ä≤ ‚ãÖ x ^ ‚Ä≤ d x ‚Ä≤ = 0 \Delta V=V(x)-V(d)=-\int_d^x 0\hat{\mathbf{x}}'\cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}'dx'=0 ŒîV=V(x)‚àíV(d)=‚àí‚à´dx‚Äã0x^‚Ä≤‚ãÖx^‚Ä≤dx‚Ä≤=0

Œî V = V ( x ) ‚àí V ( ‚àí d ) = ‚àí ‚à´ ‚àí d x 0 x ^ ‚Ä≤ ‚ãÖ x ^ ‚Ä≤ d x ‚Ä≤ = 0 \Delta V=V(x)-V(-d)=-\int_{-d}^x 0\hat{\mathbf{x}}'\cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}'dx'=0 ŒîV=V(x)‚àíV(‚àíd)=‚àí‚à´‚àídx‚Äã0x^‚Ä≤‚ãÖx^‚Ä≤dx‚Ä≤=0

giving V ( x ) = V ( ‚àí d ) = œÉ 0 d / œµ 0 V(x)=V(-d)=\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V(x)=V(‚àíd)=œÉ0‚Äãd/œµ0‚Äã. |}

  3. Plot the electric potential, V V V

{| class=‚Äùwikitable collapsible collapsed‚Äù ! align=‚Äùleft‚Äù | Answer |- | We proceed as if the dielectric is not there.

Draw a Gaussian cylinder as shown in the figure. We seek to find

Leaving

+ D A ‚àí D A = œÉ o A +DA-DA=\sigma_oA +DA‚àíDA=œÉo‚ÄãA

Inserting this magnitude for D \mathbf{D} D into the original equations gives

Left side: D = ‚àí D x ^ = ‚àí œÉ o / 2 x ^ \mathbf{D}=-D\hat{\mathbf{x}}=-\sigma_o/2\hat{\mathbf{x}} D=‚àíDx^=‚àíœÉo‚Äã/2x^

In a dielectric in general,

E = D / œµ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon E=D/œµ

so that

2.1.9 Dielectric Between Spherical Shells of Charge

2.1.10 General Rule for Computing E \mathbf{E} E?

You may find after solving a few dielectric problems using Gauss‚Äô Law that it seems as if the electric field in the dielectric is always simply E i n   d i e l e c t r i c = E o / œµ r \mathbf{E}_{in\text{ }dielectric}=\mathbf{E}_o/\epsilon_r Ein dielectric‚Äã=Eo‚Äã/œµr‚Äã, where E o \mathbf{E}_o Eo‚Äã is the electric field that would exist if the dielectric was not there.

For elementary problems involving dielectrics, this is often true. For example:

  1. One or more large square dielectrics between two large sheets of charge

  2. One or more large square dielectrics between two large capacitor plates ‚Äò‚Äô‚Äôafter‚Äô‚Äô‚Äô they are disconnected from a battery (so problem is equivalent to 1.)

    1. and 2. for one or more dielectrics between two co-aligned and long cylindrical shells

    1. and 2. for one or more dielectrics between two co-aligned and spherical shells

Incidentally, 1.-4. are all problems for which Gauss‚Äô Law for dielectrics can be used to find D \mathbf{D} D and E \mathbf{E} E.

In general, however, E i n , d i e l e c t r i c ‚â† E o / œµ r \mathbf{E}_{in,dielectric}\ne\mathbf{E}_o/\epsilon_r Ein,dielectric‚ÄãÓÄ†=Eo‚Äã/œµr‚Äã. Two examples:

  1. A large square dielectric between large capacitor plates that are held at a constant potential, V o V_o Vo‚Äã. The presence of the dielectric causes the amount of charge on the capacitor plates to increase. The electric field in the dielectric is E o / ? \mathbf{E}_o/? Eo‚Äã/? and not E o / œµ \mathbf{E}_o/\epsilon Eo‚Äã/œµ, where E o = V o / d E_o=V_o/d Eo‚Äã=Vo‚Äã/d is the electric field that existed before. This problem is covered in the section on capacitors with dielectrics.

  2. A spherical dielectric in a constant electric field, E o \mathbf{E}_o Eo‚Äã. In this situation, the induced polarization adds up in a way so that the net electric field is E o / ? \mathbf{E}_o/? Eo‚Äã/? instead of E o / œµ \mathbf{E}_o/\epsilon Eo‚Äã/œµ inside the dielectric. This problem is covered in the section on boundary value problems with dielectrics.
